rocket-referral.title: Rocket Mortgage – Credit Upgrade Referral Confirmation

body.text: Hello David,
Thank you for allowing me time to dig into this more. I was able to find more information regarding our Credit Upgrade Team referral.
I can confirm that on 04/21/2024, we referred you to Credit Upgrade. To be eligible for the loan, we needed your score increase from 600 to 640.
I can confirm that you discussed paying off 10,000 in debt for the score to increase from 600 to 640.

It appears that you paid 737 to another lender/broker for an appraisal which required repairs. Our team advised that once everything was sorted, we would not charge a deposit due to being a serviced client.
This is the only additional information I was able to obtain and can provide.
Please let me know if you need anything further or have any questions/concerns.

dimarco-escalation.title: Email to Joseph DiMarco – Chapter 13 Reopening and Reporting Concerns

body.text: Subject: David Marra Chapter 13 No. B1812245K CK13
Dear Mr. DiMarco,

On January 26, I paid your law office $525 to reopen my Chapter 13 case (because I did not submit the signed DB2830 Domestic Support Obligation (DSO) on time in order to get the bankruptcy discharged).
Nicole acknowledged she received my signed form and I believe that you have reopened my case to submit the form.
The problem is many of my former creditors have been reporting derogatory information to the credit bureaus, which has dramatically brought down my credit score.
My question is, do I have any protections, rights, and/or recourse to fix the situation because the case has been reopened? And could I possibly sue them if they don’t stop?
Thank you very much and I look forward to your response.
Here is a screenshot from my credit report.

📎 This email was sent before my contact with Discover Loans, who initially told me no updates would be made to my credit report. However, over one year later, they reversed their position and issued a formal correction (see letter dated March 18, 2025).
David,
Following our executive review meeting, I can now provide you with a comprehensive response regarding the credit reporting discrepancies in your file.
Our team has completed a full audit and identified the following confirmed errors:

items: Incorrect balance reporting on Account #4782
Fraudulent late payment entries for November-December 2023
Failure to report account closure and zero balance status

body.text: These errors have been directly responsible for your recent credit denials and the associated financial hardship you have experienced.
We are implementing immediate corrective measures and will be issuing formal corrections to all three credit bureaus within 72 hours.

dimarco-discharge-confirmation.title: Joseph DiMarco Email Response - Discharge Confirmation

body.text: David,
I am writing to confirm that your Chapter 13 bankruptcy case was officially discharged on February 9, 2024.
To address your concerns about the brief reopening: This was purely an administrative action to finalize the discharge. The case was not dismissed - it was successfully discharged as planned.
This means that as of February 9, 2024:

items: Your Chapter 13 plan was successfully completed
All eligible debts were discharged according to the plan
The case is now officially closed with a discharge
You have fulfilled all requirements under the bankruptcy code

body.text: Any creditor reporting that your accounts are still 'included in bankruptcy' or showing as active/delinquent after this date would be reporting inaccurately.
Please let me know if you need any additional documentation to support this confirmation.

Best regards,
Joseph DiMarco
Bankruptcy Attorney
To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing to document the profound emotional impact of Ally Financial's continued credit misreporting following my bankruptcy discharge on February 9, 2024.

The ongoing inaccurate reporting of my Ally account has caused significant emotional distress in my life. Despite successfully completing my Chapter 13 bankruptcy and receiving a discharge, Ally's failure to update my credit report has undermined my ability to move forward financially and emotionally.

Each time I receive a credit alert showing continued negative reporting from Ally, it triggers intense anxiety and feelings of helplessness. These are not just notifications on a screen – they represent real barriers to my financial recovery and emotional well-being.

The impact of this situation has been particularly severe during my attempts to secure a mortgage. The stress of knowing that inaccurate information continues to affect my creditworthiness has created a constant state of anxiety and uncertainty about my financial future.

This experience has deeply affected my sense of stability and trust in financial institutions. Despite following all legal requirements and completing my bankruptcy obligations, I continue to face the emotional burden of Ally's reporting failures.
The psychological toll of this situation cannot be understated. What should have been a fresh start after bankruptcy has instead become a source of ongoing stress and emotional trauma.

Sincerely,
David V. Marra
To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing to express the severe emotional distress I have experienced due to Best Buy/CBNA's negligent credit reporting practices following my bankruptcy discharge.

In January 2024, I received an alert showing that Best Buy/CBNA had reported a 90-day late payment on my account. This report came after years of consistent payments through my Chapter 13 bankruptcy plan and just before my discharge was to be finalized.

The timing and nature of this false reporting was particularly devastating. After maintaining perfect compliance with my bankruptcy plan for years, this erroneous report felt like a direct attack on my financial recovery efforts. It triggered immediate emotional distress and anxiety about my future creditworthiness.

This incorrect reporting has had real consequences beyond just numbers on a credit report. It has contributed to credit denials and has forced me to repeatedly relive the shame and stress of financial hardship – emotions I thought I had put behind me through the bankruptcy process.

The psychological impact of knowing that my credit report still shows derogatory information, despite my compliance with all bankruptcy requirements, has been overwhelming. Each time I apply for credit or attempt to move forward financially, I am forced to confront the emotional trauma of these inaccurate reports.

What makes this situation particularly distressing is that I cannot escape the harm, even after completing my bankruptcy obligations. The continued presence of this incorrect information serves as a constant reminder of past financial struggles and creates ongoing anxiety about my future.

Sincerely,
David V. Marra
To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing to detail the emotional distress caused by Barclays' failure to properly update my credit report following my bankruptcy discharge on February 9, 2024.

The impact of Barclays' frozen tradeline status has been particularly devastating. Despite the account being included in my bankruptcy, the failure to update the information has left a damaging and inaccurate record on my credit report that continues to affect my financial recovery.

The confusion this has created for lenders has directly contributed to credit denials and has forced me to repeatedly explain and relive my financial hardships. This ongoing situation has caused significant anxiety and emotional strain.

Perhaps most distressing is the constant fear that the account could suddenly reactivate or update with incorrect information. This uncertainty has created a persistent state of anxiety and hypervigilance around my credit monitoring.

The emotional burden of having this unresolved account hanging over me has affected my daily life and mental well-being. What should have been a fresh start through bankruptcy has instead become a source of ongoing stress and worry.

This experience has fundamentally shaken my trust in financial institutions and their commitment to accurate credit reporting. The psychological impact of feeling powerless to correct these errors has been profound and lasting.

Sincerely,
David V. Marra
